subject: USDJPY continues lower after Tokyo CPI data
content:
• Yen is on course to strengthen against the buck for the third straight session.
  • The USD has been under pressure after monetary authorities pump liquidity into the system, easing demand for dollars and seeing cross currency basis narrow to more normal levels; meanwhile, fiscal authorities have also continued to provide support, and the US House is expected to rubber stamp the Phase 3 virus relief bill on Friday.
  • For USDJPY, technicians are watching 109.00 (psychological) to the downside, then the 50dma at 108.97, the long-term fib at 108.59, and then the 200dma at 108.32.

subject: Nikkei 225 futures trade +4.0% in early trade, following the 6% rally on Wall Street
S&P revised ratings on German automakers due to Covid-19 (BMW GY, DAI GY both downgraded; VOW3 GY outlook revised lower)
content:
• BMW (BMW GY) ratings to A from A+; outlook negative
  • Daimler (DAI GY) was cut to BBB+ from A-.
  • Volkswagen (VOW3 GY) rating was unchanged at BBB+, though S&P moved it onto negative watch.
  • The rating agency said the revisions were linked to the duration of the Covid-19 pandemic, and its impact on the auto industry
  • The rating agency warned of steep declines in revenues and cash flows amid weaker demand

subject: APAC data slate is light; desks expect range-bound trade into the weekend, ahead of key data releases next week
RBNZ bought NZD 250mln of government bonds in QE auction (it sought NZD 250mln)
Saudi-led coalition says it intercepted and destroyed missiles fired by Yemeni Houthis, according to Saudi state news
US VP Pence says President Trump will be presented with options on opening the economy up this weekend
US health official Fauci is hopeful a vaccine will be available to tackle the next season of infections
US moving forward with plans to limit chips to Huawei, according to the WSJ
content: US moving forward with plans to limit chips to Huawei, according to the WSJ, citing sources. The proposal would require export licenses for many of the chips that are sold to Huawei that are made by US manufacturers; under the proposals, Commerce Dept could block sales of semis to TSMC. The measures would disadvantage US companies that produce semi equipment used by TSMC (could include AMAT, LRCX and KLAC). The rule will need writing, which could take weeks, sources said. Via WSJ

subject: US VP Pence says Abbott Labs (ABT) has submitted to the FDA a coronavirus test that can give results in 15 minutes
General Motors (GM) to cut marketing budget and take more measures across the company to cut costs, according to CEO Barra in a communication to staff
Bipartisan group of US lawmakers have urged the Trump administration to defer all tariffs during the covid pandemic, for at least a 90-day period, or until the crisis has passed
US President Trump says it looks like the US can do another trade deal with China, though it will have to wait until after the Presidential election
US President Trump says he has used the Defense Production Act on "two minor occasions"
US confirmed covid cases stand at 81,378 - highest in the world, according to a Reuters calculation
analysis_details: NOTE: This data is a tally by Reuters; official data earlier showed the covid case count rise to 68,440 on Thursday (from  54,453), while the official death toll was up to 994 from 737

subject: US President Trump says he will early next week provide information on relaxing guidelines on social distancing
German Chancellor Merkel says that, for Germany, the ESM is the main instrument to help other European countries during the virus crisis
US President Trump says G20 discussed importance of sharing information and data on coronavirus
EU leaders give finance ministers two weeks to sort out technical details of bailout fund credit lines for the Eurozone to fight the crisis
US HG primary market sees record volume month after supply rises to USD 195.2bln in March, according to IFR
US banks had USD 50.8bln of outstanding loans via the discount window, as of Wednesday (vs USD 28.2bln last week), according to Fed data
Fitch Affirms United States at 'AAA'; Outlook Stable
content: • Via Fitch

subject: Newsquawk US Market Wrap - 26th March 2020: Senate sends USD 2trln bill to House; record 3.3mln jobless claims
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities up, Treasuries up, Dollar down, Crude down.
  • REARVIEW: Record high 3.3mln jobless claims; USD 2trln Senate stimulus package passes Senate; US pulls plan to buy oil with SPR.
  • COMING UP: Data: US Personal Income, University of Michigan (Final) & PCE Price Index

MARKET WRAP

Stocks continued their rally after the Senate passed the USD 2trln stimulus package, which now awaits House approval on Friday. The greenback continues to reverse lower, supported by the Fed’s proactive efforts, seeing the DX fall beneath the 100 figure; note repo operations again saw minimal demand while the reverse op. continues to see heavy take-up. The abatement in scrambling for dollars is likely supporting credit markets too, where CDX IG has tightened beneath 100bps (this was above 150bp a few sessions ago and debt-driven ETFs (such as LQD, HYG, JNK, MUB, etc.), are all meaningfully off their lows (especially MUB); IFR noted that high-grade borrowers are expected to make a new weekly primary volume record as the figure is set to rise above USD 90bln. Meanwhile, oil prices suffered, particularly WTI after the stimulus failed to contain any provisions for DoE to purchase oil for the SPR.

CASE COUNT

WORLDWIDE CASES 520,395, DEATHS 23,593, RECOVERED 123,322

Figures provided as of Thursday (via worldometer website) against Wednesday:

  • CHINA total cases 81,285 (prev. 81,218), death toll 3,287 (prev. 3,281).
  • ITALY total cases 80,589 (prev. 74,386), death toll 8,215 (prev. 7,503).
  • US total cases 79,082 (prev. 68,211), death toll 1,143 (prev. 1,027).
  • SPAIN total cases 56,197 (prev. 49,515), death toll 4,145 (prev. 3,647).
  • GERMANY total cases 43,646 (prev. 37,323), death toll 239 (prev. 206).
  • FRANCE total cases 29,155 (prev. 25,233), death toll 1,696 (prev. 1,331).
  • SWITZERLAND total cases 11,712 (prev. 10,897), death toll 191 (prev. 153).
  • UK total cases 11,658 (prev. 9,529), death toll 578 (prev. 465).
  • SOUTH KOREA total cases 9,241 (prev. 9,137), death toll 131 (prev. 126).
  • NETHERLANDS total cases 7,431 (prev. 6,412), death toll 434 (prev. 356).
  • CANADA total cases 3,897 (prev. 3,409), death toll 37 (prev. 36).

Note figures are provided via worldometers thus there may be some discrepancies on figures provided against those stated from individual states.

NORTH AMERICA

STIMULUS: US Senate voted unanimously (96-0) to pass the USD 2tln coronavirus response bill which sends the bill to the House, while Senator Sasse’s amendment to change unemployment insurance provisions in the bill was voted 48-48 and fell short of the 60 needed for passage. US House Majority Leader Hoyer's office stated the House will convene at 0900EDT on Friday to consider the bill and it expected the bill will pass by voice vote, while there were also comments from House Speaker Pelosi that she is optimistic the bill will pass in the House and suggested there will be further legislation from Congress to address the coronavirus. US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin, in a CNBC interview, said direct deposits to Americans will take place within three weeks, urging the House to pass the bill as soon as possible.

CENTRAL BANKS

FED CHAIR POWELL said the Fed has the ability to use emergency lending, there is unlimited authority to lend; Powell said there could be a good rebound, and Fed is trying to ensure rebound is vigorous. US may already be in a recession; not a blank cheque, but Fed will lend aggressively, does not see risks around the Fed's recent actions, and says the Fed will not run out of ammunition when it comes to upcoming lending.

ECB stated that the self-imposed issuer limits used in QE will not apply to the temporary pandemic emergency purchase programme, according to the legal text. Subsequently, ECB'S VASILIAUSKAS said OMT is part of the ECB's toolbox and could be used. Additionally, ECB begun purchases under the emergency programme, PEPP, on Thursday.

BOE: There was little by way of new takeaways from the MPC's latst rate decision. Policy settings were unanimously kept unchanged (rates at 0.1%, total stock of asset purchases at GBP 645bln), and the Bank indicated a willingness to boost asset purchases further if needed (Governor Bailey has previously indicated a reticence to take rates negative). Commentary around the virus outbreak was striking: the MPC said the economic consequences of covid were becoming more apparent, and that there was risk of longer-term damage to the economy. It also said it has little evidence to assess the precise magnitude of the economic shock. However, it did state that the virus shock will prove temporary, particularly if job losses and business failures can be minimised. Pantheon Macroeconomics said investors may be slightly disappointed that the BOE did not follow the FOMC by committing to open-ended asset purchases of government bonds. The consultancy argues that the MPC has not formally adopted a policy of yield curve targeting, but implicitly it stands ready to step up the pace or ultimate size of its gilt purchases, if yields surge again. "Granted, the Committee seems to expect a V-shaped recovery from the virus, and it expects that sterling’s depreciation will lift CPI inflation above the 2% target next year, but for now, the Committee remains focussed on the crisis immediately before it; its expectations for rebounds in GDP and inflation won’t cause it to hold back in the near-term." Pantheon believes that QE will be escalated, should financial conditions deteriorate again, and the MPC likely will not wait until its next meeting on 7th May, if swifter action is required.

RIKSBANK, in an emergency move, said it is initiating purchases of commercial paper, and will temporarily enlarge counterparties list, to improve credit supply to companies. On April 2nd, it will purchase SEK 4bln of CP issued in SEK issued by non-financial contributions.

REST OF WORLD

G7 FOREIGN MINISTERS failed to agree on a statement on Wednesday as the Trump administration insisted on referring to the coronavirus outbreak as the Wuhan virus, something it could not find support for from the group.

DATA

US JOBLESS CLAIMS: As was widely expected, US initial jobless claims surged to a record high 3.28mln, topping te 695k claims seen in October 1982. The true picture could be much worse, according to Capital Economics, which noted that there are good reasons to believe that understandable constraints on the capacity of offices to process claims. The consultancy cites the California data, which showed less than 200k claims last week, whereas CapEco's own tracking information suggests that claims have already reached 1mln. "Based solely on the historical relationship between claims and the unemployment rate, 3,283,000 equates to an unemployment rate of somewhere between 30% and 40%," CapEco writes, "we are not suggesting the latter will rise to those levels, but we would be amazed if it didn’t exceed 10% by May, if not April." It also says that there will be a very significant drop back in unemployment when the number of new coronavirus infections fall and the economy begins to reopen, but it won’t reverse all of these losses. "The unemployment rate could remain elevated for years."

CRUDE

SETTLEMENT: WTI (K0) SETTLED USD 1.89 LOWER AT USD 22.60/BBL; BRENT (K0) SETTLED USD 1.05 LOWER AT USD 26.34/BBL.

CRUDE FUTURES TRUNDLED LOWER AFTER SPR BUYING PLAN BREAKS DOWN, failing to benefit from the pick up in equities. Note the losses were most acute in WTI following the US DoE pulling its plan to buy American oil through the SPR after the latest stimulus bill did not include such funding; although the DoE later said it still has funds for oil purchases and is in dialogue with Congress to work something out. The prospect of the SPR buying US oil had helped provide some support to the battered energy complex in recent weeks, although with this feature now seemingly evaporated, it takes the market into an even more dire environment as participants face a drop off in global demand, in addition to the ongoing supply glut. Hammering home the point, industry sources were cited on Thursday suggesting that Saudi is struggling to find buyers for its crude exports amid the demand fall off and raised freight costs. Highlighting such woes also on Thursday was IEA’s Birol, who expects a significant decline in oil demand in Q1 and even larger in Q2, suggesting global oil demand could fall by as much as 20mln BPD (20%), where a recovery would be neither easy or quick; Birol also noted that global oil storage capacity may be full very soon. Meanwhile, Goldman Sachs forecasts oil demand to to fall by 10.5mln BPD in March and 18.7mln BPD in April, adding that a demand shock of this magnitude will overwhelm any supply response including core-OPEC freeze or cut.

FIXED INCOME

TREASURY SETTLEMENT: T-NOTE (M0) FUTURES SETTLED 12+ TICKS HIGHER AT 137-23+.

THE TPLEX BULL STEEPENED as front-end Bills continued to decline into negative territory. The Fed’s monetary bazooka continues to alleviate funding pressures as O/N collateral rates remained low and minimal take-up in the repo operations, while demand in the reverse repo op continues to balloon - the negative yields in Bills are supporting Dealers’ move to park cash at the Fed. The negative front-end is also likely pushing participants further out the curve in search of yield. Elsewhere, the Treasury’s 7-year note auction was well-received, stopping through the 0.707% WI by 2.7bps, covered 2.76x (more than the six-auction average of 2.45x), and consistent with other recent auctions, dealers continue to take more than usual. By settlement, 2s10s +0.5bps at 54bps; 2-year -5bps at 0.281% and 10-year -3bps at 0.827%.

EQUITIES

CLOSING LEVELS: SPX +5.94% at 2623, NDX +5.72% at 7897, DJIA +6.24% at 22,523

SECTORS: Utilities +8.39%, Real Estate +7.81%, Health +6.98%, Financials +6.43%, Industrials +6.41%, Technology +6.35%, Energy +6.24%, Communication Svs +6.05%, Cons Stpl +5.67%, Materials +4.94%, Cons Disc +4.3%.

STOCK SPECIFICS: US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin, as according to WSJ sources, has indicated that the US would take stakes in airline names, in return for billions worth of direct grants, as part of the USD 2trln stimulus package. Airlines were strongly bid after the stimulus bill, which contains USD 58bln in aid for the industry, passed the Senate; Boeing (BA) made more double digit gains off of this. Bristol Myers (BMY) was bid on a multiple sclerosis treatment receiving FDA approval. Micron (MU) made decent gains after its strong earnings report and guidance, although analysts remain cautious. Cheesecake Factory (CAKE) announced it will not make rent payments in April as its cash flow dives lower.

FOREX

As month-end approaches, JPMorgan says navigating the next four trading days will not be easy; the bank notes that liquidity is coming at a premium and intraday ranges are significant without a great deal of news driving price action and advises traders to size accordingly.

USD: While bank's rebalancing models point towards USD buying into month/quarter-end, the dollar has seen downside on Thursday, as lawmakers in the Senate approved the fiscal stimulus bill, ahead of a House vote on Friday. Additionally, a record high jobless claims print gave the dollar a further kick down, though we were heading in that direction anyway. Desks have noted that central bank liquidity measures are working, and as a result, demand for dollars is easing, as seen in the narrowing of major cross currency basis. The DXY gave up the 100.00 handle in European trade, and later broke through 99.50.

JPY: Further desks note that Japan's GPIF is reportedly raising its allocation target for foreign bonds, from 15% to 25%; and it could be as high as 31% as it also widens the permissible range of deviation from the allocation target. Although it saw little reaction in the JPY, RBC says it brings another source of buyers for international bonds, the hedging decisions mean the currency impact may be negligible. Changes are not showing up yet in the data yet, and the weekly portfolio data overnight, showed net foreign bond purchases were close to flat for a second week running. Separately, analysts are watching yen cross-currency basis, as the USD tightness continues to ease basis has narrowed; this could impact fixed income hedging behaviour, as it becomes cheaper to hedge dollars.

EUR: Month-end factors may play a role in the days ahead, some analysts have argued; in particular, JPMorgan said Friday is the 'value month-end' which can often signify supply of EURUSD, and it told its clients that fading rallies today at around 1.10 would seem sensible enough, although the pair sits above the figure heading into APAC trade.

GBP: The BoE meeting did little for the pound, which is on course for a third straight day of gains against the EUR and the USD. Since Tuesday, GBPUSD has for the most part been straddling 1.1830 region (23.6% of March fall), and today's dollar weakness allowed cable to move just below 1.2200.

AUD: Risk currencies had a bid tone, largely sponsored by the USD downside after lawmakers made progress on fiscal stimulus. While the dollar basis has eased in major FX like EUR and JPY, it is less so with the Aussie, which technicians say may be a reason why AUD has not vaulted the 0.6075-0.6150 resistance area.

subject: Fed Chair Powell reiterates at FSOC the Fed is committed to using all tools to safeguard the economy; have taken an aggressive series of actions
Libya's NOC says oil production stands at 96k BPD as of March 25th
General Motors (GM) says it is extending suspension of its North American plant operations that originally were scheduled to end March 30th, not giving a new date for reopening
TREASURY SETTLEMENT: T-NOTE (M0) FUTURES SETTLED 12+ TICKS HIGHER AT 137-23+.
analysis_details: • THE TPLEX BULL STEEPENED as front-end Bills continued to decline into negative territory. The Fed’s monetary bazooka continues to alleviate funding pressures as O/N collateral rates remained low and minimal take-up in the repo operations, while demand in the reverse repo op continues to balloon - the negative yields in Bills are supporting Dealers’ move to park cash at the Fed. The negative front-end is also likely pushing participants further out the curve in search of yield. Elsewhere, the Treasury’s 7-year note auction was well-received, stopping through the 0.707% WI by 2.7bps, covered 2.76x (more than the six-auction average of 2.45x), and consistent with other recent auctions, dealers continue to take more than usual. By settlement, 2s10s +0.5bps at 54bps; 2-year -5bps at 0.281% and 10-year -3bps at 0.827%.

analysis_details: • CRUDE FUTURES TRUNDLED LOWER AFTER SPR BUYING PLAN BREAKS DOWN, failing to benefit from the pick up in equities. Note the losses were most acute in WTI following the US DoE pulling its plan to buy American oil through the SPR after the latest stimulus bill did not include such funding; although the DoE later said it still has funds for oil purchases and is in dialogue with Congress to work something out. The prospect of the SPR buying US oil had helped provide some support to the battered energy complex in recent weeks, although with this feature now seemingly evaporated, it takes the market into an even more dire environment as participants face a drop off in global demand, in addition to the ongoing supply glut. Hammering home the point, industry sources were cited on Thursday suggesting that Saudi is struggling to find buyers for its crude exports amid the demand fall off and raised freight costs. Highlighting such woes also on Thursday was IEA’s Birol, who expects a significant decline in oil demand in Q1 and even larger in Q2, suggesting global oil demand could fall by as much as 20mln BPD (20%), where a recovery would be neither easy or quick; Birol also noted that global oil storage capacity may be full very soon. Meanwhile, Goldman Sachs forecasts oil demand to to fall by 10.5mln BPD in March and 18.7mln BPD in April, adding that a demand shock of this magnitude will overwhelm any supply response including core-OPEC freeze or cut.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: DXY labouring below 100.000 after record breaking rise in jobless claims
content:
USD

The Dollar has been under pressure for the most part, but succumbed to more intense and all round selling after weekly US initial claims soared by almost 3.3 mn to set a fresh ATH due to the coronavirus. In fact, many suspect that the real tally could be even higher given the confinement constraints imposed to contain COVID-19 and closure of offices collating and processing benefit applications, so next Thursday’s number could be similar if not bigger. The index was already looking vulnerable to a deeper retreat and duly lost grip of the psychological century handle on the way through technical support at 99.800 (38.2% Fib retracement of the 94.650-102.990 move from ytd base to apex), plus 99.667 (former peak from October 2019) to leave 99.500 exposed.

GBP/JPY/NZD/AUD/EUR/CHF/CAD 

All extending gains vs the Greenback, as Cable rebounds further from last week’s pre-2000 lows just pips away from 1.1400 to circa 1.2130, albeit from a loftier sub-1.1800 platform and not really gleaning much from the BoE or UK retail sales data. For the record, the MPC let policy alone after 2 emergency meetings to cut rates and also increase the APF at the latter one when the Bank rate was reduced to the lower bound, while headline consumption was considerably weaker than forecast, but consigned to the pre-nCoV pile of economic indicators. Elsewhere, the Yen ignored a decent upturn in risk sentiment in stocks if not all assets to probe above 109.50, with Buck weakness overshadowing any loss of safe-haven appeal. On that note, the previously underperforming non-US Dollars took advantage of their counterpart’s ongoing demise as the Kiwi and Aussie recovered from around 0.5780 and 0.5870 respectively to 0.5950+ and 0.6060+, while the Loonie resumed its revival to test offers/resistance close to 1.4000. Returning to Europe, round numbers were breached by the Euro and Franc, at 1.1000 and 0.9700, with the latter also scaling 0.9650 at one stage.

SCANDI/EM 

The aforementioned accelerated Usd reversal coupled with renewed risk appetite came to the rescue of Scandinavian Crowns and regional currencies that were floundering, including the Czk irrespective of the CNB’s more aggressive than envisaged rate cut (-75 bp vs -50 bp consensus) and dovish policy guidance. Note, Governor Rusnok revealed that there is a covert level for FX intervention, but refused to air what the line in the sand is.

ANALYSIS: True jobless claims could be much worse than today's data suggests, according to Capital Economics
analysis_details: As was widely expected, US initial jobless claims surged to a record high 3.28mln, topping the 695k claims seen in October 1982. The true picture could be much worse, according to Capital Economics, which noted that there are good reasons to believe that understandable constraints on the capacity of offices to process claims. The consultancy cites the California data, which showed less than 200k claims last week, whereas CapEco's own tracking information suggests that claims have already reached 1mln. "Based solely on the historical relationship between claims and the unemployment rate, 3,283,000 equates to an unemployment rate of somewhere between 30% and 40%," CapEco writes, "we are not suggesting the latter will rise to those levels, but we would be amazed if it didn’t exceed 10% by May, if not April." It also says that there will be a very significant drop back in unemployment when the number of new coronavirus infections fall and the economy begins to reopen, but it won’t reverse all of these losses. "The unemployment rate could remain elevated for years."

US Cash Equity Open: a solid start on Wall St. post jobless claims and stimulus passage in the Senate
content:
US equity futures picked up in pre-market action back towards overnight highs following grim initial jobless claims data, which although was the worst on record, was not as bad as the 'whisper' number had suggested, news organisations said. 

ES cleared 2,500 after the cash open; traders noted that Senators finally passed the USD 2trln stimulus bill, and the House is likely to follow in a vote on Friday. 

Sectors wise, all eleven major sectors are in positive territory after the open with consumer staples and health care at the top of the leader board; for indsutrials, Boeing (BA) and American Airlines (AAL) are among the top performers amid government support for airlines. Meanwhile, Micron (MU) is performing well after a decent earnings report and guidance after market on Wednesday. Apple is paring back some of the losses after a Nikkei sources story on Wednesday, which stated it was mulling a delay of its 5G iPhone launch.Ahead, the focus should be back on the case counts and death toll of the coronavirus; risk around the US stimulus bill has diminished now, somewhat.

Q3 EPS view 0.40-0.70 (exp. 0.57), Q3 Revenue view 4.6blnbln-5.2bln (exp. 4.86bln). Co says the lower consumer demand in China has been offset by stronger data center demand as gaming, e-commerce, and remote-work activity demand picks up; says data center demand for Q3 "looks strong" and is leading to supply shortages. BOE keeps rates unchanged at 0.1% in a unanimous decision; says economic consequences of covid are becoming more apparent. There is risk of longer-term damage to the economy; Little evidence to assess the precise magnitude of the economic shock
content:
• Is ready to act further, can expand asset purchases if needed
  • Inflation likely to fall beneath 1% in the Spring; Unemployment likely to rise rapidly across a range of economies
  • BOE says it will monitor inflation and inflation expectations carefully; notes inflation will be boosted by the depreciation of GBP
  • PMIs are pointing to a material contraction in GDP
  • Says conditions have tightened materially; BOE saw widespread evidence to the disruption of market functioning
  • Virus shock will prove temporary, particularly if job losses and business failures can be minimised
  • MPC voted unanimously to maintain Bank Rate at 0.1%, also voted unanimously to continue with the programme of GBP 200bln of UK govt bond and sterling non-financial investment-grade corporate bond purchases, financed by the issuance of central bank reserves, to take the total stock of these purchases to GBP 645 billion.
  • Full statement
analysis_details:
• There was little by way of new takeaways from the MPC's latst rate decision. Policy settings were unanimously kept unchanged (rates at 0.1%, total stock of asset purchases at GBP 645bln), and the Bank indicated a willingness to boost asset purchases further if needed (Governor Bailey has previously indicated a reticence to take rates negative). 
  • Commentary around the virus outbreak was striking: the MPC said the economic consequences of covid were becoming more apparent, and that there was risk of longer-term damage to the economy. It also said it has little evidence to assess the precise magnitude of the economic shock. However, it did state that the virus shock will prove temporary, particularly if job losses and business failures can be minimised. 
  • Pantheon Macroeconomics said investors may be slightly disappointed that the BOE did not follow the FOMC by committing to open-ended asset purchases of government bonds. The consultancy argues that the MPC has not formally adopted a policy of yield curve targeting, but implicitly it stands ready to step up the pace or ultimate size of its gilt purchases, if yields surge again. "Granted, the Committee seems to expect a V-shaped recovery from the virus, and it expects that sterling’s depreciation will lift CPI inflation above the 2% target next year, but for now, the Committee remains focussed on the crisis immediately before it; its expectations for rebounds in GDP and inflation won’t cause it to hold back in the near-term." 
  • Pantheon believes that QE will be escalated, should financial conditions deteriorate again, and the MPC likely will not wait until its next meeting on 7th May, if swifter action is required.

ECB has no plans to deploy the OMT emergency bond purchase to counter the coronavirus, according to sources; sees the EUR 750bln pandemic emergency purchase programme as a more powerful tool to counter the crisis
analysis_details:
• Earlier, ECB's Vasiliauskas said OMT is part of the ECB's toolbox and could be used
  • Outright Monetary Transactions were not formally discussed at the latest ECB meeting but it was brought up, with sources noting that there is broad support of activating it in time of crisis
  • This will allow the ECB to buy almost unlimited amounts of govt debt from stressed-EUR area countries
  • Some analysts have suggested that the OMT programme has already been made redundant by the ECB's new PEPP; the final sentence of the ECB's PEPP statement last Wednesday reads stated that "the ECB will not tolerate any risks to the smooth transmission of its monetary policy in all jurisdictions of the euro area" - on the same day, Italy's central bank was reportedly purchasing bonds to maintain monetary transition.
  • Furthermore, OMTs have a duration of three years, whereas PEPP bonds will indefinitely stay on the European Central Bank's balance sheet - thus spreading the cost of borrowing over a longer horizon and keeping annual costs subdued.

subject: Newsquawk Daily US Opening News - 26th March 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European price action has been choppy equity-wise, as focus remains on the progression of stimulus as well as the rising COVID-19 count
  • US Senate voted unanimously (96-0) to pass the USD 2tln coronavirus response bill which sends the bill to the House
  • US House Majority Leader Hoyer's office stated the House will convene at 0900EDT on Friday to consider the bill
  • Spain's total coronavirus cases rise to 56,188 on Thursday from 47,610 on Wednesday
  • ECB stated the self-imposed issuer limits used in QE will not apply to the temporary pandemic emergency purchase programme; ECB says they have today begun purchases under this
  • FX sees the DXY approaching the 100.00 mark to the downside, much to the benefit of G10 peers
  • Looking ahead, highlights include BoE Rate Decision, US GDP (Final), PCE Price (Final), & Initial Jobless Claims, Fed’s Bullard, supply from the US

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

US Senate voted unanimously (96-0) to pass the USD 2tln coronavirus response bill which sends the bill to the House, while Senator Sasse’s amendment to change unemployment insurance provisions in the bill was voted 48-48 and fell short of the 60 needed for passage. (Newswires)

US President Trump said he approved disaster declarations by various states and said probably some sections of the country can return to work before other sections. President Trump also stated Congress is very close to passing stimulus bill and that he will sign coronavirus relief bill as soon as it reaches his desk, while he added they are open to more stimulus and suggested they will go back for more money if needed. (Newswires)

US House Majority Leader Hoyer's office stated the House will convene at 0900EDT on Friday to consider the bill and it expected the bill will pass by voice vote, while there were also comments from House Speaker Pelosi that she is optimistic the bill will pass in the House and suggested there will be further legislation from Congress to address the coronavirus. (Newswires)

G7 Foreign Minister failed to agree on a statement on Wednesday as the Trump administration insisted on referring to the coronavirus outbreak as the Wuhan virus. In related news, China and US are expected to set aside their coronavirus blame game and focus on the challenges of the pandemic when G20 leaders hold a video conference today. (Washington Post/Twitter/SCMP)

Spain's total coronavirus cases rise to 56,188 on Thursday from 47,610 on Wednesday; death toll 4,089 from 3,434 on Wednesday. (Newswires)

UK coronavirus cases rose to 9529 from 8077 and death toll rose to 463 from 422. (Newswires)

Italian PM Conte is aiming for a new stimulus package worth in excess of EUR 25bln. (Newswires)

Mainland China reported 67 additional cases and 6 additional deaths on March 25th vs. 47 additional cases and 4 deaths on March 24th, which brings the total number of cases in mainland China to 81285 and the total death toll to 3287. (Newswires)

South Korea reported 104 additional coronavirus cases to take total to 9241 and 5 additional deaths for a total of 131, while there were 414 newly recovered to take the total to 4144. (Newswires)

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded cautiously amid headwinds from the US where most major indices finished in the green although pulled back heading into the Wall St. close after the USD 2tln coronavirus relief bill hit a snag at the Senate. This follows reports GOP Senators Graham, Sasse and Scott noted they won't speed up the bill until a drafting error in the stimulus bill is addressed which otherwise could provide an incentive for employees to be laid off, while Democrat Senator Sanders threatened he will demand restrictions on USD 500bln fund for corporates if the 3 Republican Senators do not drop their objections to unemployment insurance expansions. Nonetheless, the bill was eventually passed via unanimous vote which gets sent to the House for a vote on Friday. ASX 200 (+2.3%) gained as the RBA remained active in its QE efforts and with notable outperformance in tech and defensive sectors such as healthcare and utilities. Nikkei 225 (-4.5%) was heavily pressured as exporters including index heavyweight Fast Retailing staggered on the detrimental currency flows and with SoftBank also among the worst hit after its credit rating was downgraded 2 notches and deeper into junk status by Moody’s, while participants were also ruffled by the Tokyo Governor’s requests for residents to stay at home during the weekend to curb the spread of COVID-19. Hang Seng (-0.7%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.6%) were indecisive as focus also shifted to earnings including the upcoming releases by the Big 4 banks which are set to begin announcing their results from today. Finally, 10yr JGBs were higher due to the underperformance of risk sentiment in Japan and following similar rebound in T-notes, with weaker results at the latest 40yr JGB auction doing little to stall the overnight bond rally.

PBoC skipped open market operations and sold CNY 10bln of 6-month bills in Hong Kong. (Newswires) PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 7.0692 vs. Exp. 7.0839 (Prev. 7.0742)

Japanese government lowers its economic assessment in March; situation is seen as "severe" due to COVID-19 and removes language which described the economy as "recovering" for 1st time in nearly 7 years. (Newswires)

BoJ board member Adachi says there is now need to take additional steps now but is carefully watching developments. Additionally, Adachi says there is scope to lower rates further into negative territory but such a move will only be an option after the economy emerges from the hit imposed by COVID-19. (Newswires)

BoK is planning weekly repo purchase system and is to expand operations for 3 months to provide unlimited liquidity which a BoK official can be viewed as QE, while the BoK is said to be concerned about possible quarter-end liquidity crunch at financial institutions and may purchase more government bonds if required. (Newswires)

Singapore GDP (Q1) Q/Q -10.6% vs. Exp. -6.3% (Prev. 0.6%)

Singapore GDP (Q1) Y/Y -2.2% vs. Exp. -1.5% (Prev. 1.0%)

US

Fed Chair Powell says Fed has the ability to use emergency lending, there is unlimited authority to lend; Powell says there could be a good rebound, and Fed is trying to ensure rebound is vigorous. US may already be in a recession; not a blank cheque, but Fed will lend aggressively, does not see risks around the Fed's recent actions, and says the Fed will not run out of ammunition when it comes to upcoming lending. (Newswires)

UK/EU

ECB stated the self-imposed issuer limits used in QE will not apply to the temporary pandemic emergency purchase programme, according to the legal text. (Newswires) Subsequently, ECB's Vasiliauskas says OMT is part of the ECB's toolbox and could be used. Additionally, ECB have begun purchases under the emergency programme today, PEPP.

UK Retail Sales MM (Feb) -0.3% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. 0.9%, Rev. 1.1%); YY 0.0% vs. Exp. 0.8% (Prev. 0.8%, Rev. 0.9%)

GEOPOLITICS

There were reports of explosions in Baghdad's Green Zone in Iraq and that sirens are sounding at the US Embassy, while other reports noted that 2 rockets were launched at the Green Zone area. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European equity markets remain under-pressure (Euro Stoxx 50 -2.2%) and are on course to snap its two-day winning streak following a mostly downbeat APAC session. The positive sentiment faded following the anticipated passage of the US coronavirus bill through Senate, with eyes now on the House vote – with House Speaker Pelosi refusing to provide timings as the legislation needs to be closely examined. US equity futures also succumb to the broad stock sell-off as traders eye the key initial jobless claims data due at 1230GMT as an initial gauge of the COVID-19 impact on State-side jobs.  In terms of Europe, cash and futures markets remain off lows with modest outperformance seen in Italy; FTSE MIB (-1.0%) – potentially on reports that the ECB will not apply issuer limits on its EUR 750bln QE bazooka, meaning that bond purchase cap at 33% of each country’s debt will not apply under the PEPP. Sectors all reside in negative territory with underperformance seen in Energy, whilst Industrials benefit from softer energy and base metal prices, broad-based losses are seen across the sector breakdown (ex-industrial goods and services). In terms of individual movers, Casino (-5.2%) sees downside post-earnings after suspending guidance. ABN AMRO (-3.9%) shares fell after announcing an incidental net loss of EUR 200mln which will be included in its Q1 20 results. Finally, Barclays (-2.2%) experiences headwinds from lower yields and mounting doubts regarding its promised GBP 1.03bln dividend pay-out next week.

Norwegian Sovereign Wealth fund are likely to re-balance via the purchase of stocks; will not comment on when or how fast the increase in share portfolio will take place. (Newswires)

FX

JPY - A marked change of fortunes amidst yet another twist in the risk roller-coaster has propelled the Yen back to the top of the major ranks and dragged Usd/Jpy down from 111.50+ peaks through 111.00 on the way towards 109.80, with Yen crosses also retreating even though other G10 currencies are benefiting from a more pronounced pull-back in the Greenback and DXY in return (index now hovering near the base of a new, lower 101.020-100.330 range).

EUR/CHF - The single currency continues to track broader Buck and overall sentiment movements rather than COVID-19 Eurozone economic contagion evident most recently in a much more pronounced deterioration in Gfk German consumer confidence and the IW institute warning that GDP could contract by 10% at worst. However, Eur/Usd has now breached resistance ahead of 1.0900 to test 1.0950 before the next set of upside chart levels at 1.0964 and 1.0981 that are protecting 1.1000 where 1 bn option expiries roll off. Similarly, the Franc is eyeing higher ground vs the Dollar at 0.9700, while keeping pace with the Euro as the cross meanders between 1.0653-20.

NZD/CAD/AUD/GBP - All firmer against the Usd, albeit less so and more wary about renewed risk aversion, with the Kiwi cresting 0.5850, Loonie testing 1.4150 and Aussie capped into 0.6000. Elsewhere, the Pound has been choppy again as Cable settles down around the 1.1900 handle having been up to circa 1.1960 from sub-1.1800 lows at one stage and now waiting for the BoE after largely shrugging off UK retail sales given that the reported figures pre-dated nCoV. Note, our full preview of the March MPC policy meeting is available via the Research Suite.

SCANDI/EM - Some loss of bullish momentum due to further erosion of risk appetite and a downturn in crude alongside other commodities, but the Swedish Krona has also had to contend with worrying declines in industrial and consumer morale, while the Czech Koruna is conscious that the CNB is widely tipped to lower rates by another 50 bp on top of the emergency ease of the same magnitude, and may even signal QE.

Notable FX Expiries, NY Cut:

-       EUR/USD: 1.0800 (1BLN), 1.0900 (230M), 1.0925 (241M), 1.1000 (1BLN)

-       GBP/USD: 1.2000 (1.4BLN)

-       USD/JPY: 108.75 (1.1BLN), 110.00 (742M), 110.75 (350M), 111.00 (480M), 112.00 (1BLN)

-       EUR/JPY: 120.85 (860M)

FIXED

Core bonds remain bid, albeit off peaks as the Eurozone periphery and French OATs continue to outperform on ECB PEPP factors, as debt markets await words from the FOMC chair before the spotlight switches to the UK for the official March policy confab. However, Gilts did forge a fresh 135.82 Liffe peak prior to easing back and market contacts note a bullish Short Sterling futures trade via options in advance of midday with the Jun20 99.875 middle butterfly netted for 1.25 and 1.5 ticks in 25k lots. Looking a bit further ahead, US weekly claims will be the pm data highlight amidst ramped up COVID-19 expectations, but Usd32 bn 7 year supply also rounds off this week’s Treasury issuance remit.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent front-month futures continue to bleed as sentiment ticks back into broad risk aversion and with underlying fundamentals still bearish for both the demand and supply side of the equation. WTI futures lurk under USD 24/bbl while its Brent counterpart eyes 26.50/bbl to the downside, with both benchmarks around session lows at the time of writing. Participants will be closely watching today’s G20 call; sources expect the oil market to be discussed, at least as part of the wider economy, although an outright oil market discussion was rebuffed by Russia’s Kremlin. The Trump Administration also reportedly asked Saudi Arabia to hold off on plans to ramp up production to 12.3mln BPD in April (vs. 9.7mln BPD in March), whilst also asking the Kingdom to bring oil prices back to levels before the crude crash – a sign that US suppliers cannot tolerate prolonged periods of sub-30/bbl prices. The sources added that Saudi has no intention of changing course at the moment as it attempts to force Russia’s hand into production curtailments. Interestingly, in 1986 the US attempted to convince Saudi to abandon the price war at the time, an attempt that proved to be futile and the price war continued for another six months. Elsewhere, spot gold remains subdued and meanders around the USD 1600/oz – with investors favouring govt debt and haven FX in flights to safety given the yellow metal’s recent liquidity-induced selloff. Copper prices move in tandem with the risk aversion and almost reversed yesterday’s gains, albeit the red metal keeps its head above 2/lb.

CME raised COMEX 5000 silver futures maintenance margins by 12.5% to USD 9000/contract and raised palladium futures NYMEX margins by 13.2% to USD 43000/contract from USD 38000/contract. (Newswires)

Goldman Sachs forecasts oil demand to fall by 10.5mln bpd in March and 18.7mln bpd in April, while it suggested that a demand shock of this magnitude will overwhelm any supply response including core-OPEC freeze or cut. However, Goldman Sachs also noted it is seeing increasingly risks of a price rebound to be sharper than its base-case rally back to USD 40/bbl for Brent by Q4 2020. (Newswires)

Russian Kremlin says the G20 summit will not discuss oil markets, discussions will likely focus on the economic impact of COVID-19. (Newswires)

subject: Fed Chair Powell says Fed still has policy room; says there could be a good rebound, Fed trying to ensure rebound will be vigorous; US may already be in a recession
content:
• Powell says he listens to the experts; virus will dictate timing; expects economic activity will resume in H2 2020
  • Fed has the ability to use emergency lending, has unlimited authority to lend
  • Powell says it is not a blank cheque, but Fed will lend aggressively; Fed stands ready to step in wherever credit is not flowing
  • Powell says the aim is to support flows of credit into the economy, which is only limited by US Treasury backstops
  • Powell says this crisis is not a 'typical downturn'
  • Powell says there could be a good rebound on the other side of this crisis
  • The Fed chair does not see risks around the Fed's recent actions, and says the Fed will not run out of ammunition when it comes to upcoming lending

subject: Many European airlines have cash for less than a two-month shutdown, according to a IATA Official

subject: Daily European Equity Opening News
content:
26th March 2020

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0200CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0200CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0215CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0250CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0215CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asia equity markets traded cautiously amid headwinds from the US where most major indices finished in the green although pulled back heading into the Wall St. close after the USD 2tln coronavirus relief bill hit a snag at the Senate. This follows reports GOP Senators Graham, Sasse and Scott noted they won't speed up the bill until a drafting error in the stimulus bill is addressed which otherwise could provide an incentive for employees to be laid off, while Democrat Senator Sanders threatened he will demand restrictions on USD 500bln fund for corporates if the 3 Republican Senators do not drop their objections to unemployment insurance expansions. Nonetheless, the bill was eventually passed via unanimous vote which gets sent to the House for a vote on Friday. ASX 200 (+2.3%) gained as the RBA remained active in its QE efforts and with notable outperformance in tech and defensive sectors such as healthcare and utilities. Nikkei 225 (-5.0%) was heavily pressured as exporters including index heavyweight Fast Retailing staggered on the detrimental currency flows and with SoftBank also among the worst hit after its credit rating was downgraded 2 notches and deeper into junk status by Moody’s, while participants were also ruffled by the Tokyo Governor’s requests for residents to stay at home during the weekend to avoid a coronavirus explosion. Hang Seng (-0.9%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.3%) were indecisive as focus also shifted to earnings including the upcoming releases by the Big 4 banks which are set to begin announcing their results from today.

FTSE 100

Associated British Foods (ABF LN) - Primark has refused to pay its rent bill as it seeks more support from landlords. (Telegraph)

Barclays (BARC LN) – Co. is to waive overdraft charges until end-April to allow extra user headroom given the virus. (FT)

Flight Names – Airlines are asking the Government to underwrite hundreds of millions in regulatory and air traffic control charges, according to a Airlines UK letter sent to Transport Secretary Shapps. (Sky News)

Housing Names – UK property demand has dropped 40% last week, according to Zoopla research; foreseeing a 60% for the next 3-months. (FT)

Intu (INTU LN) – Co. is to reportedly notify of a virus induced revenue slump which would state it has received circa 30% of the rental payments they normally would. (Sky News)

UK Banks - The Times reports that doubts are continuing to mount over whether Barclays (BARC LN) will pay a promised GBP 1.03bln dividend next week, whilst RBS (RBS LN) are also reportedly debating whether to payout GBP 968mln in May amid pressure by the BoE and Treasury for banks to conserve cash and help support struggling companies. (Times) Separately, Banks have come under criticism from firms and the UK Government as they have been insisting that personal guarantees are provided for the provision of gov’t backed loans to businesses given the virus. (BBC News)

EX-DIVS: British American Tobacco (BATS LN), British Land Company (BLND LN), Ferguson (FERG LN), Prudential (PRU LN), Pearson (PSON LN), Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS LN), and (Schroders SDR LN) will trade without entitlement to its latest dividend pay-out on Thursday, trimming 9.8 points off the FTSE 100. subject: Newsquawk Daily European Opening News - 26th March 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

·        US Senate voted unanimously (96-0) to pass the USD 2tln coronavirus response bill which sends the bill to the House

·        US House Majority Leader Hoyer's office stated the House will convene at 0900EDT on Friday to consider the bill

·        Asia equity markets traded cautiously amid headwinds from the US where most major indices finished in the green although pulled back heading into the Wall St. close

·        In FX markets, the DXY softened and retreated back below the 101.00 level; EUR/USD above 1.09, USD/JPY below 111.00

·        Looking ahead, highlights include German GfK, UK Retail Sales, BoE Rate Decision, US GDP (Final), PCE Price (Final), & Initial Jobless Claims, Fed’s Bullard, supply from the US

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

US Senate voted unanimously (96-0) to pass the USD 2tln coronavirus response bill which sends the bill to the House, while Senator Sasse’s amendment to change unemployment insurance provisions in the bill was voted 48-48 and fell short of the 60 needed for passage. (Newswires)

US President Trump said he approved disaster declarations by various states and said probably some sections of the country can return to work before other sections. President Trump also stated Congress is very close to passing stimulus bill and that he will sign coronavirus relief bill as soon as it reaches his desk, while he added they are open to more stimulus and suggested they will go back for more money if needed. (Newswires)

US House Majority Leader Hoyer's office stated the House will convene at 0900EDT on Friday to consider the bill and it expected the bill will pass by voice vote, while there were also comments from House Speaker Pelosi that she is optimistic the bill will pass in the House and suggested there will be further legislation from Congress to address the coronavirus. (Newswires)

US Defense Secretary Esper issued a stop movement order to halt all travel and movement abroad for up to 60 days, while Washington D.C. ordered all non-essential businesses to close through to April 24th. (Newswires)

G7 Foreign Minister failed to agree on a statement on Wednesday as the Trump administration insisted on referring to the coronavirus outbreak as the Wuhan virus. In related news, China and US are expected to set aside their coronavirus blame game and focus on the challenges of the pandemic when G20 leaders hold a video conference today. (Washington Post/Twitter/SCMP)

Italy COVID-19 total cases rose to 74,386 (prev. 69,176) and the death toll rises to 7,503 (prev. 6,820). There were also comments from Italian PM Conte that the government is working on extra measures to support the economy on the same scale as the EUR 25bln already announced. (Newswires)

UK coronavirus cases rose to 9529 from 8077 and death toll rose to 463 from 422. (Newswires)

Mainland China reported 67 additional cases and 6 additional deaths on March 25th vs. 47 additional cases and 4 deaths on March 24th, which brings the total number of cases in mainland China to 81285 and the total death toll to 3287. (Newswires)

South Korea reported 104 additional coronavirus cases to take total to 9241 and 5 additional deaths for a total of 131, while there were 414 newly recovered to take the total to 4144. (Newswires)

ASIA

Asia equity markets traded cautiously amid headwinds from the US where most major indices finished in the green although pulled back heading into the Wall St. close after the USD 2tln coronavirus relief bill hit a snag at the Senate. This follows reports GOP Senators Graham, Sasse and Scott noted they won't speed up the bill until a drafting error in the stimulus bill is addressed which otherwise could provide an incentive for employees to be laid off, while Democrat Senator Sanders threatened he will demand restrictions on USD 500bln fund for corporates if the 3 Republican Senators do not drop their objections to unemployment insurance expansions. Nonetheless, the bill was eventually passed via unanimous vote which gets sent to the House for a vote on Friday. ASX 200 (+2.3%) gained as the RBA remained active in its QE efforts and with notable outperformance in tech and defensive sectors such as healthcare and utilities. Nikkei 225 (-5.0%) was heavily pressured as exporters including index heavyweight Fast Retailing staggered on the detrimental currency flows and with SoftBank also among the worst hit after its credit rating was downgraded 2 notches and deeper into junk status by Moody’s, while participants were also ruffled by the Tokyo Governor’s requests for residents to stay at home during the weekend to curb the spread of COVID-19. Hang Seng (-0.9%) and Shanghai Comp. (-0.3%) were indecisive as focus also shifted to earnings including the upcoming releases by the Big 4 banks which are set to begin announcing their results from today. Finally, 10yr JGBs were higher due to the underperformance of risk sentiment in Japan and following similar rebound in T-notes, with weaker results at the latest 40yr JGB auction doing little to stall the overnight bond rally.

PBoC skipped open market operations and sold CNY 10bln of 6-month bills in Hong Kong. (Newswires) PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 7.0692 vs. Exp. 7.0839 (Prev. 7.0742)

BoK is planning weekly repo purchase system and is to expand operations for 3 months to provide unlimited liquidity which a BoK official can be viewed as QE, while the BoK is said to be concerned about possible quarter-end liquidity crunch at financial institutions and may purchase more government bonds if required. (Newswires)

Singapore GDP (Q1) Q/Q -10.6% vs. Exp. -6.3% (Prev. 0.6%)

Singapore GDP (Q1) Y/Y -2.2% vs. Exp. -1.5% (Prev. 1.0%)

UK/EU

ECB stated the self-imposed issuer limits used in QE will not apply to the temporary pandemic emergency purchase programme, according to the legal text. (Newswires)

FX

In FX markets, the DXY softened and retreated back below the 101.00 level amid the brief stimulus bill snag at the Senate. Nonetheless, the greenback’s losses were limited amid mixed price action in its major counterparts and ahead of today’s US GDP and jobless claims data, as well as Fed Chair Powell’s rare televised interview at 0705EDT. EUR/USD extended on its gains but was off its highs as it battled to hold on to the recently reclaimed 1.0900 handle and GBP/USD consolidated after a failed attempt at 1.1900. Elsewhere, USD/JPY slipped firmly below 111.00 owing to the continued USD-reversal although eventually found a base around 110.50, while antipodeans were choppy as the ill-effects to the high beta currencies from the indecisive risk tone was offset following a surprise firmer fixing by the PBoC and the unanimous passage of the record stimulus bill at the US Senate.

COMMODITIES

Commodities were subdued amid the indecisive risk tone overnight which kept oil prices rangebound around USD 24.00/bbl after the prior session’s choppy performance where the latest EIA inventory report showed a narrower than expected build, albeit still at an increase compared to the surprise draw seen in the latest private sector inventories. Furthermore, there were mixed comments overnight from Goldman Sachs which suggested the significant expected drop to demand this and next month would overshadow any action by OPEC, but also suggested risks of a potential sharper rebound for Brent crude in Q4. Elsewhere, gold prices were stuck around the USD1600/oz level and failed to benefit from the pull back in USD, while copper conformed to the lacklustre tone across the complex amid the mixed risk tone and weakness in its largest purchaser China.

CME raised COMEX 5000 silver futures maintenance margins by 12.5% to USD 9000/contract and raised palladium futures NYMEX margins by 13.2% to USD 43000/contract from USD 38000/contract. (Newswires)

Goldman Sachs forecasts oil demand to fall by 10.5mln bpd in March and 18.7mln bpd in April, while it suggested that a demand shock of this magnitude will overwhelm any supply response including core-OPEC freeze or cut. However, Goldman Sachs also noted it is seeing increasingly risks of a price rebound to be sharper than its base-case rally back to USD 40/bbl for Brent by Q4 2020. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICS

There were reports of explosions in Baghdad's Green Zone in Iraq and that sirens are sounding at the US Embassy, while other reports noted that 2 rockets were launched at the Green Zone area. (Newswires)

US

The TPLEX bull steepened on Wednesday, likely catching momentum from the short-end, where some Bills crossed into negative rates. With a strong take-up in the Fed’s reverse repo operation, and low overnight collateral rates, dealers have enough cash for the time being, which is potentially pushing them into Bills. Furthermore, the Treasury’s 5-year note auction was well received, stopping through the 0.55% WI by 1.5bps, while covering 2.53x (above the six-auction average of 2.42x), dealers took a larger share than usual, but one desk notes the strong takeup as not a “hot-potato toss”, but rather a desire for the notes, instead of immediately selling them. Meanwhile, the belly to long-end likely saw less of a bid due to the equity rally, as well as the increased corporate supply. By settlement, 3m -6bps at -0.0457%, 2s -4.5bps at 0.332%, 10s +3.5bps at 0.853%, 30s +4.5bps at 1.414%. Spreads: 2s10s +4.4bps at 51bps, 2s30s +6.5bps at 108bps; 3-month FRA-OIS +5bps at 106bps. T-note (M0) futures settled 3+ ticks lower at 137-11.

subject: ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia trades mixed as markets await Senate bill vote outcome
content:
Asia equity markets trade cautious amid headwinds from the US where most major indices finished in the green although pulled back heading into the close after the USD 2tln coronavirus relief bill hit a snag at the Senate. This follows reports GOP Senators Graham, Sasse and Scott noted they won't speed up the bill until a drafting error in the stimulus bill is addressed which otherwise could provide an incentive for employees to be laid off, while Democrat Senator Sanders threatened he will demand restrictions on USD 500bln fund for corporates if the 3 Republican Senators do not drop their objections to unemployment insurance expansions. ASX 200 (+1.9%) is led higher as the RBA remain active in its QE efforts and with notable outperformance in tech and defensive sectors such as healthcare and utilities, while Nikkei (-3.8%) is heavily pressured as exporters including index heavyweight Fast Retailing stagger on the detrimental currency flows and with SoftBank also among the worst hit after its credit rating was lowered 2 notches and deeper into junk status by Moody’s. Hang Seng (-0.9%) and Shanghai Comp. (Unch.) were also indecisive as focus also shifts to earnings including the upcoming releases by the Big 4 banks which are set to begin announcing their results from today.

In FX markets, the DXY softened and has retreated back below the 101.00 level amid the stimulus bill snag at the Senate and with the recent stronger than expected headline Durable Goods data doing little to spur the currency. Nonetheless, the greenback’s losses are limited amid mixed price action in its major counterparts with EUR/USD off its highs as it struggles to hold on to the recently reclaimed 1.0900 handle and with GBP/USD consolidating after a failed attempt at 1.1900. Elsewhere, USD/JPY slipped firmly below 111.00 owing to the continued USD-reversal although eventually found a base around 110.50, while antipodeans are choppy alongside the indecisive risk tone and following a surprise firmer fixing by the PBoC.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are higher due to the underperformance of risk sentiment in Japan and following similar rebound in T-noted, but with gains capped ahead of a 40yr auction later.
